awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a Cloud Based Instrument for Heterogeneous Biomedical Body Sensor Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project, developing a cloud-based instrument, aims to aggregate data driven from an array of body sensors. The instrument can be used in a wide range of wearable sensor-based medical applications. The proponents investigate research challenges focused on Biomedical Body Sensor Data Acquisition, Transmission, and Analysis. Recent advances in cloud computing and sensor technologies have made feasible to develop a software instrument that is able to integrate all aspects of heterogeneous biomedical body sensor systems, from sensor data preprocessing, transmission, and critical event detection at sensor side, to data reliability evaluation and enhancement, data analysis, sensor control at data aggregator (usually a smart phone or PC), and finally data storage, retrieval, and further extensive analysis at the cloud server. 

Build jointly with UT-Dallas, the instrument development includes: 1. Android developing; 2. Mobile cloud computing; 3. Cloud infrastructure and set up; 4. Cloud API and Sensor side APUI; 5. Reliability Enhancement, and 6. Event detection. Its major components include: 1. A cloud cluster to support data storage/indexing analysis; 2. APIs for sensor side data preprocessing, critical event detection, and transmission strategies based on open source platform TinyOS; 3. Mobile App development ; and 4. API for sensor data access and analysis algorithms evaluation.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of the funded research include:

1. Instrument Acquisition, setup, and development: (i) A five-node cloud cluster has been acquisited and setup. (ii) An Android App for bluetooth based data collection through Shimmer biomedical sensor motes. The App is able to perform real-time data analysis and send requests to the cloud server to perform analysis of most recent samples. (iii) A data and algorithm repository function oriented web portal was implemented to facilitate convenient data uploading and algorithm contribution. (iv) Instrument source codes have been shared publicly on GitLab.

2. Investigation of several key research issues: (i) Multi-level Sample Importance Ranking Based Progressive Transmission Strategy for Time Series Body Sensor Data. (ii) Adaptation of the IEEE 802.15.6 WBAN MAC to use the EAP (Exclusive Access Phase) phase to enhance the quality of service support when data analysis request is received. (iii) Virtual Patient Model: An Approach for Generating Synthetic Healthcare Time Series Data. (iv) design of a context aware and self adaptive body sensor data analysis scheduling. Results have been published in major conferences such as BodyNets, ICNC, ICHI, and Computer Networks Journal.

3. Data collection and evaluation of the prototype. We have collaborated with Dallas VA Research Corporation to collect live motion data from recruited stroke patients to test the feasibility of the prototype. A comprehensive evaluation of the integrated prototype with Android App, Web Portal, and Cloud Server. Experimental results have been published in BodyNets 2020. 


Last Modified: 01/24/2022
Modified by: Ming Li
